awd_titl_txt: Accelerating STEM Learning Through Large-Scale Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from NSF's Accelerating Discovery program, investigators at Rice University will design and implement the Learning in Education Research Network (LERN) to study and harness the complex factors that propel human learning.  The central idea is that carefully designed, large-scale learning studies involving large numbers of students and teachers, coupled with modern data science tools, can provide insight into the factors that underpin student learning.  Researchers have long sought to determine the predictors of academic success and persistence since such predictions could enable preemptive interventions for students at risk for failure.  However, these studies have usually examined populations of students rather than individuals.  The population focus limits prediction to groups of students rather than to individuals.  The LERN project intends to take advantage of rapid technological advances to develop individually tailored ways of studying learning, shifting the science of learning away from population-based thinking and towards individual-based thinking.  In this way, the project intends to contribute to personalized learning, so individually tailored approaches can be used to address each student's differences in learning and achievement.

The individual-based approach to be studied in LERN is characterized by an emphasis on how individual differences affect learning outcomes, and how these differences interact with learning interventions.  The project intends to develop: (1) new data science tools to measure students' individual differences and their interactions with authentic digital learning environments; (2) a large-scale infrastructure to scientifically manipulate students' learning experiences; (3) a suite of targeted experiments and studies that leverage large numbers of students; and (4) a study fusing student individual differences and learning interaction data with socioeconomic and demographic data.  LERN will use OpenStax, a digital learning platform, to study multiple factor interactions in learning across large numbers of students in Houston, Texas.  The project intends to develop a set of data science tools, including adaptive assessment and digital highlighting and annotation, that will allow examination of individual differences and learning behaviors including locus of control and academic mindset.  These efforts are intended to shift the course of educational research from population-based to individual-based, thus setting the stage for personalized learning.  These efforts complement the National Science Foundation's focus on Harnessing the Data Revolution by harnessing data science approaches to understand and improve student learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This was a comprehensive project that aimed to address five key themes: A) developing new tools to measure student individual differences and their interactions with authentic digital learning environments; B) developing new data science tools to analyze student individual differences and learning data; C) build large-scale infrastructure to scientifically manipulate students’ learning experiences that build on Rice University’s OpenStax digital learning platform; D) suite of powerful, targeted experiments and studies that leverage the large populations of students using OpenStax digital texts to test and validate both the individual difference concept and the experimental infrastructure; and E) a first-of-its-kind study fusing student individual differences and learning interaction data with socioeconomic and demographic data from college and high school students in Houston, Texas. By design, the project’s research team reflected deep-level diversity along almost every dimension: disciplines (e.g., education, computer science), research interests (e.g., goal setting, learning strategies, skills), methodological and statistical approaches (e.g., quantitative and qualitative; learning/training interventions; measuring stable and dynamic learner characteristics), career and life experiences (e.g., practitioners and professors, early and later career stage; race/ethnicity, gender, and age).

We made significant strides for all five themes. Most notably, we developed the OpenStax Kinetic research platform (C) focused on postsecondary adult learners using OpenStax resources and engaging them in learning sciences research to address key questions such as who the learners are, what they are learning, and how they are learning. Kinetic produced a range of important outcomes and eventually paved the way for SafeInsights (NSF # 2153481), the first education Mid-Scale Research Infrastructure II from the STEM-EDU directorate. This $90M award will support the development of a privacy-preserving, cross-platform education research and development (R&D) infrastructure and includes 13 edtech platforms spanning K-16+ levels, 12 research institutions, 39 postsecondary institutions, and six policy, privacy, and other thought partners.

We iteratively improved Kinetic while leveraging its research capabilities to further the goals of developing new instruments to measure individual differences and interactions with authentic learning contexts (A), develop targeted research studies (D), and identify promising avenues to explore the development of data science tools for learning analytics (B). First, the Learner Characteristics Library (LCL), including core measures of learner characteristics that impact learning outcomes, is available to Kinetic researchers for use in their own research. The LCL enables the standardized use of these instruments for each construct of interest to increase the cross-study generalizability of research conducted using Kinetic data. Second, we conducted user research to improve the learner and researcher experiences on Kinetic and created efficiencies in the research process with a streamlined researcher onboarding and study creation flow. Further, by introducing digital badges as our new participation incentive, Kinetic created a more scalable approach to conduct large-scale learning research while providing a rewarding user experience for online learners. Third, we analyzed our findings from Kinetic’s large-scale research studies, ranging from descriptive findings of learner characteristics (e.g., vocational interest, self-efficacy) to interventional research designs (e.g., different forms of online modes of delivery on retention; brief writing tasks) exploring the impacts of intervention on learning retention. We disseminated our research in education conferences and industry presentations to build awareness of Kinetic’s capabilities and goals. Fourth, we initiated a research-practice partnership effort by convening a group of seven higher education professionals, including those from minority-serving institutions and a tribal college. This working group provided insights from the field to understand the current needs of postsecondary students from various sociodemographic groups, broader inequities in educational experiences, and how to shape future education practices to provide greater support to all learners. 

Finally, our Houston Education Research Consortium (HERC) team conducted extensive investigations with the Houston Independent School District (HISD) to identify STEM deserts in the district, as well as STEM endorsements and their impact on different socio-demographic groups. Key findings from the theme E research included that Black students from low socioeconomic groups were likely to be in STEM deserts; female students were less likely to choose STEM endorsements irrespective of socioeconomic status, and this gender gap was reduced with district counseling; and finally, STEM endorsement was positively associated with the decision to attend a more selective college. We shared these findings with HISD and initiated discussions about how to communicate to high school students the advantages of choosing a STEM endorsement, and its accompanying career and workforce pathways, and foster district-wide change.

Ultimately, the project furthered learning science by facilitating large-scale online learning research that provides an engaging user experience for participants, by exploring differences in high school students’ STEM access and decisions at one of the largest and most diverse school districts in the United States, and by laying the groundwork for how Kinetic can join with other learning initiatives to understand learners holistically while incorporating privacy into the infrastructure’s core design.
